questions.text: All the following features are more commonly seen in crohns disease as compared to ulcerative colitis except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mucosal friability and risk for adenocarcinoma of colon is more with ulcerative colitis. And the risk of adenoca is directly proportional to the extent of bowel involvement and duration of disease. LGI bleeding is also seen more commonly with UC.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who has ulcerative colitis is admitted to the hospital because of fever, bloody diarrhea, and abdominal tenderness.Medical treatment, including the use of parenteral steroids, is started. During the next several days, the woman becomes increasingly ill; an abdominal X-ray now shows a transverse-colon diameter of 12 cm but no free intraperitoneal air. The treatment of choice would be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Toxic megacolon is a complication of fulminant ulcerative colitis and affects 2 to 5% of persons with the disorder. Although toxic megacolon can be a reversible process, operative intervention is indicated if clinical deterioration and marked colon dilation have not been controlled by a trial of medical therapy, including administration of steroids. The operation of choice, in the absence of perforation, is total proctocolectomy and ileostomy.

questions.text: Crohn’s disease can be seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Crohns is a Chronic, transmural inflammatory disease of the GIT for which the cause is unknown It can involve any part of the alimentary tract from the mouth to the anus, but most commonly affects the small intestine and colon.

questions.text: Cobble stone appearance is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In crohn's disease linear ulcers join together with transverse sinuses and leave an area of normal mucosa in between. This is referred to as Cobblestone appearance.

questions.text: String sign of Kantor seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The gastrointestinal string sign (also known as the string sign of Kantor) refers to the string-like appearance of a contrast-filled bowel loop caused by its severe narrowing. Originally used to describe the reversible narrowing caused by spasms in Crohn disease,

choices.text: It is separate and distinct form ulcerative colitis
Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Rectum spared in 50% patients with large bowel involvement

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Crohn’s disease is incorrect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rectal sparing is a characteristic feature of patients with crohn’s disease. It is not involved in crohn’s disease. Option A. Presence of a non caseating granuloma with langhans giant cells in bowel wall is a characteristic histologic lesion in patients of crohn’s disease. Option B. Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are distinct lesions different from one another . Option C. Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for crohn’s disease. Cigarette smoking is protective for ulcerative colitis.

choices.text: Non-cutting setons are used in management

questions.text: True statement regarding anorectal Crohn’s disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A. Perianal disease is seen in 20 % of patients of crohn’s disease. It presents as Ulceration, Fistula or strictures. Ulcerations are the most common presenting features. Option B. Fistulas are a common feature of perianal involvement in crohn’s disease. Fistulas are painless and are indurated in nature. Option C. Fistulotomy is the treatment option for fistula management in crohn’s disease. Fistulas in crohn’s disease are managed by seton placement. Infliximab is the treatment of choice for treatment of fistulas. While the patient is on infliximab we put non cutting seton for the management of crohn’s disease fistulas.

questions.text: Ulcerative colitis starts from:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ulcerative colitis starts in rectum and then progresses cranially to involve rest of the bowel. Rectal involvement is a hallmark of ulcerative colitis. Rectal sparing is a feature of crohn’s disease.

questions.text: Crohn’s disease is best diagnosed by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Best diagnostic test for Crohn’s disease is enteroclysis. Enteroclysis is an examination of the small bowel. X-rays are used to take single pictures and a special form of x-ray called fluoroscopy is also used in this examination. The radiologist can see internal organs like the bowel in motion using fluoroscopy

questions.text: Characteristic of Crohn’s disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Transmural involvement that is involvement of all the layers of the wall of the intestine and skip lesions are the characteristic features of crohn’s disease. Option B. Large bowel involvement can occur in patients of crohn’s disease but its is not characteristic feature of crohn’s disease Option C. Pseudopolyps can be seen in patients of crohn’s disease but it is not characteristic of crohn’s disease as pseudopolyps are also present in ulcerative colitis. Option D. In crohn’s disease there is transmural involvement, involvement of mucosa alone is a feature of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: All are true about ulcerative colitis except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stricture formation is a feature of crohn’s disease and not ulcerative colitis. Option A. Ulcerative colitis starts from the rectum with anal sparing .In some cases ileum is also inflammed which is referred to back wash ileitis. Option C. Risk of malignancy in ulcerative colitis increases with the duration of the disease. Most cases have malignancy development after around 10 years of disease process. Option D. Crypt abscess is a feature of ulcerative colitis but it is not a specific finding. Crypt abscess can be seen even in crohn’s disease.

questions.text: UC can be differentiated from Crohn’s disease by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pseudopolyps can occur in both ulcerative colitis and crohn’s disease. They are more common in ulcerative colitis but they can not be used to distinguish one from another. Options B,C and D. Rectal sparing, discontinuous or skip lesions and deep longitudinal ulcers are a feature of crohn’s disease.

questions.text: Ulcerative colitis involves:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C & E) In ulcerative colitis we have partial wall involvement, so in ulcerative colitis only mucosa and submucosa is involved. In Crohn’s disease patients there is transmural involvement so all the layers of the intestine are involved.

questions.text: In a 27-years old male, most common cause of a colovesical fistula would be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Common causes of colovesical fistula: Diverticulitis (50–60 % More common in patients > 40 years) CA colon (20–25% More common in patients > 50 years) Crohn’s disease (10% Seen in 2nd to 3rd decade)

questions.text: The commonest site of involvement in the Crohn’s disease is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Commonest site for involvement in crohn’s disease is Terminal ileum Commonest site for involvement in ulcerative colitis is Rectum

choices.text: Diagnosis of the extent of inflammation

questions.text: The indications of colonoscopy in a patient with ulcerative colitis are all of the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) For diagnosis of toxic megacolon we need to go for radiological investigations and look for the diameter of the bowel . If transverse colon is dilated > 6cm it is diagnostic of toxic megacolon. Indications of Colonoscopy : To establish the extent of inflammation To distinguish between UC and Crohn’s disease To monitor the response of treatment To assess long standing cases for malignant change

questions.text: Crohn’s disease is associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The identification in 2001 of the CARD-15/NOD2 mutation (on chromosome 16q, also known as IBD1 locus) provided first definitive genetic link to the condition and is relatively specific for Crohn’s disease.

questions.text: In ulcerative colitis, after colectomy least likely to resolve is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) All extraintestinal manifestations resolve after surgery except A) Ankylosing Spondylitis B) Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis Option D. Erythema Nodosum is the most responsive to treatment in IBD .

questions.text: All are true associations of ulcerative colitis except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B & D) Circinate balanitis is seen in Reiter’s syndrome, not in ulcerative colitis. Aphthous stomatitis is a feature of crohn’s disease not ulcerative colitis as in crohn’s disease any part of GIT from mouth to anus can be affected.

questions.text: Most common stones in ulcerative colitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In IBD patients we find oxalate stones. M/c stones in ulcerative colitis is Ammonium urate whereas in Crohn's disease is Calcium oxalate .

questions.text: Surgical indications in inflammatory bowel diseases are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Presence of extraintestinal complications is not an indication of surgery in IBD. These patients can be managed by medical therapy as well. If patient has developed obstruction, we need to operate and relieve the obstruction. If there is a perianal complication, stricture formation or malignancy, it needs to be treated by surgical intervention.

choices.text: Pouch operation is done for fulminant ulcerative colitis
2% case of Crohn’s disease undergo malignant changes
Ulcerative colitis don’t undergo malignant changes

questions.text: True statements about inflammatory bowel disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ? Pouch operation (total proctocolectomy with IPAA) is not done during fulminant ulcerative colitis Fulminant ulcerative colitis not responding to medication is an indication for emergency operation In emergency operations, total abdominal colectomy with ileostomy is done The risk of malignancy in Crohn’s pancolitis is similar to UC pancolitis, i.e. 2% after 10 years, 8% after 20 years and 18% after 30 years approximately

questions.text: Which sulphonamide is used for the treatment of ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Salazopyrin is brand name of sulfasalazine. Sulfasalazine is a combination of 5- ASA and Sulphapyridine. In this 5-ASA acts as the anti inflammatory agent and sulphapyridine acts as a carrier of 5-ASA.

questions.text: Best treatment for remission of acute ulcerative colitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Glucocorticoids that is hydrocortisone and methylprednisolone acts by inducing remission. They have no role to be played in maintenance therapy. Options A and D. 5 Aminosalicylic acid and sulfasalazine that has 5 ASA acts as a mainstay of therapy in UC and CD

choices.text: Presence of dysplasia on colonic biopsy
Failure of response to medical therapy of acute colitis

questions.text: Not an indication for surgery in ulcerative colitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pancolitis is not an indication of surgery in ulcerative colitis patients. Options A, C and D. Presence of dysplasia on colonic biopsy, toxic megacolon and failure of response to medical therapy in acute colitis are the definitive indications of surgery in ulcerative colitis

choices.text: Takes at least 10 years to develop
Associated with dysplasia of the rest of the colon
Younger age of onset is associated with increased chance of carcinoma

questions.text: Not true about malignancy arising from ulcerative colitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Colitis Associated Colon Cancer (CAC):- Arise from flat dysplasia or dysplasia associated lesion or mass Multiple synchronous colon cancer in 12% Mean age: 30 years, Distributed uniformly throughout the colon

questions.text: Toxic megacolon is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Toxic megacolon is a serious life-threatening condition that can occur in patients with ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s colitis, and infectious colitides such as pseudomembranous colitis This decompensation results in a necrotic thin-walled bowel in which pneumatosis can often be seen radiographically.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in toxic megacolon:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In toxic megacolon medical treatment is associated with a high rate of recurrence with subsequent urgent operation. Total abdominal colectomy with ileostomy and preservation of the rectum is treatment of choice for toxic megacolon. It serves the main purpose of removing the diseased colon and avoiding a difficult and morbid pelvic dissection.

questions.text: Incidence of pouchitis in patients treated for ulcerative colitis with IPAA is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inflammation of the mucosa of the ileal pouch, or pouchitis, occurs in 7-33% of patients with UC treated by IPAA The cause is unknown but may be related to bacterial overgrowth, mucosal ischemia, or other local factors Clinical features: •Pouchitis typically presents with increased stool frequency, fever, bleeding, cramps, and dehydration Treatment: •Episodes usually respond to rehydration and oral antibiotics, usually metronidazole or ciprofloxacin •Probiotics have been reported to provide dramatic resolution in some cases of pouchitis resistant to antibiotic therapy •The diagnosis of Crohn’s disease must also be entertained in patients with significant pouchitis that does not respond to medical treatment

questions.text: Most common cause of death in Crohn’s disease is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Most common cause of death in crohns is malignancy.

choices.text: Conservative treatment and leave him and hope for the spontaneous resolution
Perform laparotomy and check for leakage site and healthy margins
Perform laparotomy and completely exteriorize the fistula
Perform laparotomy and place drain and leave

questions.text: A patient of Crohn’s disease underwent resection anastomosis. Now present on 7th post-op day with anastomotic leak from a fistula. Every day leakage volume adds up to 150–200 ml. There is no intra-abdominal collection and the patient is stable without any complaints. What will be next line of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Successful management requires establishment of controlled drainage, usually using a sump suction apparatus; management of sepsis; prevention of fluid and electrolyte depletion; protection of the skin; and provision of adequate nutrition When sepsis has been controlled and nutritional therapy has been instituted, a course of conservative management should be followed. Most of these fistulas heal spontaneously within 4–6 weeks of conservative management. If closure is not accomplished after this time,surgery indicated.

choices.text: A resection margin of 2 cm from gross disease.
A resection margin of 12 cm from gross disease.
A resection margin 2 cm from microscopic disease on frozen section.
A resection margin 12 cm from microscopic disease on frozen section

questions.text: In the resection of a stenotic area of intestine in a patient with Crohn’s disease, the best approach is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) There are no differences in the recurrence rates or resection with a 2-cm margin or a 12-cm margin from gross disease. The additional bowel lost may contribute to eventual short gut syndrome in a patient who requires multiple resections, so minimizing bowel loss is a priority. There is no benefit to achieving frozen section negative margins in the resection of Crohn’s strictures; positive margin resections have the same recurrence rate as negative margin resections.

choices.text: Liver, biliary tree, joints, skin, eyes

questions.text: What structures are most likely to be sites of extracolonic disease in inflammatory bowel disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The liver is a common site for extracolonic disease in inflammatory bowel disease. Fatty infiltration of the liver is present in 40 to 50% of patients, and cirrhosis is found in 2 to 5%. Primary sclerosing cholangiitis is a progressive disease characterized by intra- and extrahepatic bile duct strictures. Bile duct carcinoma is a rare complication of long-standing inflammatory bowel disease. Arthritis also is a common extracolonic manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease, and the incidence is 20 times greater than in the general population. Erythema nodosum is seen in 5 to 15% of patients with inflammatory bowel disease and usually coincides with clinical disease activity. Pyoderma gangrenosum is an uncommon but serious condition that occurs almost exclusively in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. Up to 10% of patients with inflammatory bowel disease will develop ocular lesions. These include uveitis, iritis, episcleritis, and conjunctivitis.

choices.text: Deep and broad ulcer located in the lateral position.
Shallow and broad ulcer located in the anterior position.
Deep and narrow ulcer located in the posterior midline position.
Shallow and narrow ulcer located in the lateral position

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe pain on defecation that began 2 months ago. On rectal examination, a fissure is found. What would indicate that this fissure is due to Crohn disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Typically, a fissure from Crohn disease is particularly deep or broad and perhaps better described as an anal ulcer. These fissures are often multiple and located in a lateral position rather than anterior or posterior midline as seen in an idiopathic fissure in ano. A classic-appearing fissure in ano located laterally should raise the suspicion of Crohn disease
